AirFlinger Android SDK

The TVersity AirFlinger SDK provides all the necessary building blocks to add media shifting capabilities to mobile apps and more specifically to create engaging multi-screen experiences.

See:
          Description

Packages
com.tversity.airflinger.sdk.android Classes that provide the main functionality of the SDK, allowing "Flinging" of media to target devices.
com.tversity.airflinger.sdk.android.assets Classes that provide a uniform access to media items, either local on the device, or remote on a media server.

 

The TVersity AirFlinger SDK provides all the necessary building blocks to add media shifting capabilities to mobile apps and more specifically to create engaging multi-screen experiences. Its main features are media shifting of local/remote/web content, screen mirroring, and control plus synchronization during playback.

Using this SDK you can:

  • Discover devices on the network and interact with those devices.
  • Stream content from various sources including the web, the host device (device on which the SDK is running) and other sources.
  • Control playback of streamed content including play, pause, stop, seek, volume controls and so on.
We distinguish between two types of devices, players and servers:
  • Players can receive media over the network and render it.
  • Servers represent a source of content with the capability to provide metadata with respect to the content they host as well as deliver that content over the network.

The SDK encapsulates multiple industry standards, thus allowing a wider range of devices to be supported. Each standard utilizes a different terminology for a player and a server. For example, the UPnP and DLNA standards refer to them as Media Renderer and Media Server while the Miracast standard refers to them as Sink and Source devices.

This Java SDK is designed for developing applications for the Android operating system. It is thread safe, but is designed for being used from a GUI application without the need to handle threads or network related issues. Therefore, whenever a method of this SDK returns an asynchronous response, it will be sent in the main thread of the application.

To start using the SDK, begin with the AirFlinger class. Using this class you initialize the SDK and get a collection of media devices identified on the network.
Once you have the collection of devices, you can control them or query them using the subclasses of the Device.
With an Player class, you can get information and control playback of media on a media renderer device.
With a Server class, you can get information and browse the media available on a media server.

The assets package provides classes for an easy and uniform access to media items.
With these classes one can browse and access local media items on the device, or remote media items on a media server.
